textBeforeTable: Professionals[edit] This is an extremely important aspect of randonneuring, where "riders aim to complete the course within specified time limits, and receive equal recognition regardless of their finishing order.". So there is no actual "winner" but a "first place finisher" Although the History of PBP website mentions that half a decade ago PBP started as a race, according to the official PBP website "the organizers strongly feel that PBP is not a race". Winners[edit] Since 1991, the starting and finishing point has been in Saint-Quentin-en-Yvelines, 22 km southwest of Paris. The 2007 Paris–Brest–Paris was the first poor weather event since 1987. It was the worst weather PBP riders had faced since 1956. 30.2% failed to finish. Normally the rate of non-finishers is around 15%. Susan Notorangelo set a women's record of 54 hours 40 minutes in 1983, but that was obliterated in 1995 when it fell to Brigitte Kerlouet 44 hours 14 minutes. American Melinda Lyon finished as first woman in 1999 and 2003. In 2007 the first woman was Christiane Thibault, and in 2011 it was Isabelle Esclangon, both from France. American Scott Dickson came third in 1979, though at just less than 49 hours he was four hours behind the winners. In 1983 he again came third, this time by only one hour.
